content.text: Bruxism is the involuntary grinding, gnashing, or clenching of teeth. Sleep bruxism occurs during sleep and is classified as a sleep-related movement disorder.
Adult prevalence is estimated around 8-13%, with higher rates in children. Most people are unaware they grind their teeth until a partner notices or a dentist spots wear patterns.
Sleep bruxism is an arousal-motor coupling disorder. Brief microarousals during sleep trigger rhythmic masticatory muscle activity (RMMA).

items: Autonomic activation builds minutes before an episode
EEG arousal occurs seconds before
A brief heart-rate spike precedes jaw muscle activation
Grinding is the motor expression of that arousal

content.text: Force is not the main danger; average sleep bite force is far below maximum waking clench. The risk comes from unregulated duration and reduced protective reflexes during sleep.
Because episodes are tied to arousal, the most effective strategy is reducing arousal triggers and interrupting episodes with biofeedback.
Sleep bruxism is typically managed rather than cured. Genetic arousal thresholds and long-term patterns mean the goal is fewer episodes, less pain, and protection of teeth.

items: Teeth grinding or clenching loud enough to wake your partner
Teeth that are flattened, fractured, chipped, or loose
Worn tooth enamel exposing deeper layers
Increased tooth sensitivity or pain
Tired or tight jaw muscles, especially upon waking
Jaw, neck, or face pain or soreness
Dull headache starting at the temples
Sleep disruption for you or your partner

content.text: The exact cause of bruxism isn't fully understood, but research has identified several risk factors:

items: Stress, anxiety, or tension (most common trigger)
Sleep disorders like obstructive sleep apnea
Abnormal bite or missing/crooked teeth
Lifestyle factors: caffeine (~1.5x odds), alcohol (~2x odds), smoking (>2x odds)
Certain medications, especially SSRIs (responsible for ~74% of reported antidepressant-induced bruxism cases)
Genetic factors
GERD/LPR (acid reflux) - associated in case-control studies and can trigger episodes
Arousal dysregulation and frequent microarousals during sleep
Neurochemical factors (GABA, dopamine, serotonin, noradrenaline, glutamate)

content.text: Evidence indicates reflux can trigger sleep bruxism episodes. The relationship is bidirectional but reflux to bruxism is the dominant proven direction.
Treating reflux removes an upstream trigger: strict diet phase, meal timing, alginate therapy (Gaviscon Advance), head-of-bed elevation, and PPI timing for nocturnal suppression.
No single intervention cures bruxism, but a strategic combination of evidence-based approaches can effectively manage symptoms:

items.name: Night Guards
items.description: Custom-fitted hard acrylic splints protect teeth. Soft splints can worsen bruxism in many patients; hard stabilization splints are preferred.

items.name: Biofeedback
items.description: EMG-based biofeedback with gentle alerts can interrupt grinding during the microarousal window. Trials show multi-week reductions, though habituation can occur.

items.name: Lifestyle Changes
items.description: Reduce caffeine and alcohol, follow reflux-trigger elimination, and avoid late meals. Sleep hygiene and meal timing help reduce arousal triggers.

items.name: Stress Management
items.description: Mindfulness, slow breathing, and yoga reduce arousal and daytime clenching; useful alongside other treatments.

items.name: Medication Review
items.description: If bruxism started after beginning an SSRI, discuss with your doctor (never stop abruptly). Buspirone may help after 2-3 weeks.

items.name: Botox (Severe Cases)
items.description: Effective for pain and force reduction, but expensive and requires ongoing treatment.

items.name: Reflux Protocol (LPR)
items.description: Treat reflux as an upstream trigger: strict 6-week trigger elimination, meal timing, Gaviscon Advance/alginate, head-of-bed elevation, and appropriate PPI timing.

items.name: Sleep Hygiene & Wind-Down
items.description: Consistent sleep/wake timing, cool dark room, screen-free hour before bed, and a structured wind-down reduce microarousals.

items.name: Supplements (Magnesium, L-Theanine, Glycine)
items.description: Magnesium glycinate (400-600mg), L-theanine (200mg), and glycine (3g) before bed can support inhibitory tone and sleep quality. Optional and best combined with upstream measures.

items: Morning: delay breakfast 1.5-2 hours, hydrate toward 3L/day, vitamin D + multivitamin, 5-10 min light exposure, 10-20 min mindfulness, check sleep/EMG data.
Meals: eat upright, no drinks with meals, water about 30 min after, remain upright 1 hour after, avoid trigger foods.
Afternoon: no caffeine after 2pm, moderate exercise (end at least 4 hours before bed), no alcohol.
Dinner/Evening: finish dinner 3+ hours before bed, light meal, no food after dinner, stay upright, dim lights, no screens 1 hour before bed.
Bedtime: warm bath, gentle stretching, optional taVNS, slow breathing, bedtime supplements, Gaviscon Advance, body scan, insert hard splint, activate EMG tracker, lights out.
Sleep environment: head-of-bed elevation 10-25 cm, 18-22C, dark/quiet room, 7-8 hours, consistent sleep/wake times.

Strict 6-week phase: avoid caffeine (including decaf), carbonation, alcohol, chocolate, spicy, acidic, fatty/fried, onions/garlic in large amounts, very salty/crispy foods; reintroduce one at a time afterward.
Weekly/ongoing: aerobic exercise 3-4x/week, review EMG/sleep trends, nature exposure.
Monthly/ongoing: blood tests (Mg, Zn, B6, Vitamin D) every 3-6 months while on PPI, reassess protocol monthly, ENT follow-up around March 2026.

content.text: OpenJaw uses EMG (electromyography) monitoring through a Muse headband to detect jaw muscle activity during sleep.
When clenching is detected, your Apple Watch delivers a gentle haptic vibration to interrupt the grinding pattern without fully waking you.
Biofeedback targets the microarousal window and can reduce EMG activity over multiple weeks, though habituation can occur in some users.

Beyond real-time biofeedback, OpenJaw provides a central place to track all your bruxism management habits, monitor your progress over time, and access evidence-based information to help you take control of your treatment.
Best results come from combining biofeedback with upstream arousal reduction: reflux control, sleep hygiene, and stress management.
